data.text: Contents
Parent administration of medication in paediatrics policy / MSEPO-21198 / 1.0
Page  of
Parent administration of medication in paediatrics policy / MSEPO-21xxx / 0.03
Introduction
The effective management of a child's medication regimen often relies on input and understanding from parents.
By encouraging parents/carers to learn or continue to take responsibility for medication during their child's hospital stay, it is expected that:
Child's routine is maintained, and parents/carers are empowered to be involved in the child's normal care;
Understanding and familiarity with current medication will be maintained and enhanced and ‘normal routine' is followed;
Parents can be educated on any new medication which may be added during the child's stay and gain experience with dosing before discharge;
Doses are given in a timely manner by parents/carers without the need to rely on ward staff to administer medication if the ward is busy and the workload is high
Patient's preference for different formulations can be considered;
Any additional educational needs regarding medication will be highlighted at the earliest opportunity and addressed before discharge.
Scope
This policy sets out the principles for parents/carers administering the child's medication whilst admitted to the Children's Ward, highlighting best practice.
It aims to allow parents/carers who are:
Normally familiar with and responsible for the child's medication to continue to administer this medication whilst the child is in hospital.
Learning to care for children with long term conditions to take autonomy for the child's normal care during the transitional phase of discharge planning.
Definitions

table_items.text: Those persons up to sixteen years of age
For the purposes of this document this is used as a generic phrase which includes guardians/carers where appropriate

data.text: Page  of
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Quality Governance Group
Receiving and noting or actioning exceptions raised by Medicines Assurance Group concerning the parent administration of medicines scheme.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group (MAG)
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalate concerns to the Chief Nurse or site Director of Nursing and Chief Medical Officer or Paediatric Medical Director as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Quality Governance Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning the parent administration of medicines.
MSE Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Reporting policy compliance auditing;
Coordinating and providing support for process and system changes to reduce the likelihood of non-compliance and medication errors occurring and recurring;
Reporting into Medicines Assurance Group as appropriate for the subject material.
Paediatric Services Governance Group
Reviewing audit data and taking action with respect to service delivery;
Ensuring attendance and engagement at Medication Optimisation and Safety Group;
Ensuring involvement of the paediatric clinical pharmacy team in issues related to operation of this policy.
Chief Executive
Ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Site Paediatric Clinical Lead
Ensures existing medical / nursing staff is aware of this policy at the point of policy dissemination;
Ensures new medical / nursing staff is made aware of this policy at induction.
Page  of
Site Clinical Lead Pharmacist
Ensuring all pharmacists who cover the Children's ward (including in the absence of the regular ward pharmacist) are aware of and understand this policy and how it is managed.
Ensures any deviation from the policy is investigated by paediatric pharmacists at each site and any such deviations reported back into the site pharmacy leadership meetings.
Deputy Director of Nursing (Paediatrics and Neonates)
Ensuring that there is safe and effective implementation of this policy and maintained compliance in all areas they are responsible for;
Ensuring there are the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) available for all staff they oversee;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated parent administration of medicines issues involving professions and staff they oversee are appropriately managed corporately;
Ensures medication errors are reported and investigated in a complete and
timely manner.
Site Head of Nursing for Paediatrics
Ensuring Ward/department manager/s are implementing and monitoring this policy in their areas;
Ensuring areas under their responsibility are appropriately monitored and supported following audit to ensure sustained improvement is achieved;
Reporting medication errors and near miss incidents involving this policy using the Trust's incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
Medical Staff
Ensuring all prescriptions are written clearly and unambiguously;
Ensuring any changes to medicines included in the policy are clearly communicated to the nursing staff and parents and that any alterations to drug charts are clear;
Ensuring any decision made by medical staff to exclude a child or parent from the policy is clearly communicated to nursing staff;
Ensuring all current medications are prescribed in a timely manner as soon as the patient has been assessed for discharge (i.e. a full history on discharge prescription sheet);
Ensuring there is no delay with the discharge prescription by liaising with senior medical staff as necessary.
Page  of
Registered Nursing Staff
To identify participants for the policy and undertaking parent assessment in accordance with Appendix 1 and Appendix 2 (file in patient records);
To liaise with medical staff, Ward Manager and Ward Pharmacist as appropriate, where there is any doubt regarding the suitability of a child/parent for participation in the Policy;
To state and discuss the Parent Guidelines with the parent and gaining written consent (Appendix 3), giving a copy to the parent and taking a copy for the patient records;
Escalate any medication-related problems to the ward pharmacist, in order that these can be identified and resolved in a timely manner;
To ensure drug charts are clearly marked with a ‘Parents Medication Policy' sticker and ensure that those medicines included in the policy are identified on the chart.

To monitor the compliance of this policy, they are required to liaise frequently with the parents throughout the shift (Appendix 3). The nurse will be required to administer the medications exempt from this scheme including;
To check suitability for re-use of all medications brought in by parents and to seek parental consent for any medicines requiring destruction;

Inform the pharmacist covering the ward of any medication alterations, additions or suspensions as soon as the prescription has been amended; in order to ensure that medications supplied are accurate and up to date;
Ensure that the prescription sheet is checked at regular intervals, which is dependent on the medication prescribed, throughout each shift in order to ensure that there are no omissions;
Ensure that all medication supplied at discharge is in accordance with the discharge medication prescription and is clearly labelled with instructions.
Pharmacy Staff
To assist in resolving medication-related issues escalated by medical or nursing staff;
Provide medicines-related information when requested by parents or nursing staff. Ensure the provision of suitably labeled medication;
On request, to assess suitability for use of dispensed items (patient's own medications) and re-dispense / re-label items where indicated.
Page  of
Key points
All patients on this parent medication policy must be nursed, where possible, in a side room that accommodates a parent lockable medication locker.
Parents must be made aware that they can withdraw from the policy at any time, provided they inform nursing staff immediately of this decision.
All parents involved in the child's care whilst in hospital must complete individual assessments.
Communication is essential. The doctor responsible for the patient together with the pharmacist must be informed of any problems encountered to enable prompt resolution.
Medication exempt from this policy are controlled drugs, ‘as required' medications, and intravenous/injectable medications excluding insulin.
Medication is stored in a designated parent lockable and locked medication locker. Only the child's medicines are permitted to be kept in the parent drug locker.
Discharge as per standard procedure for patients not under this scheme.
Eligibility criteria
Children on existing medications:
Children admitted to the children's wards who are taking regular medication for chronic illness on admission;
Parents are informed about the policy and consent to take part.
OR
New patients:
Children who will be on medication for 3 months or more (“long term”) and whose parents are learning how to give the new medications;
Parents are informed about the policy and must give consent in order to take part.
Page  of
Assessment and documentation

Eligibility for the policy must be assessed by a Registered Nurse and/or Registered Pharmacist using the assessment sheet (Appendix 2). A copy of the assessment documentation must be kept in the patient record and a copy given to the parent.
All parents involved in the care of the child whilst in hospital must be assessed on an individual basis.
Registered Nurse and/or Registered Pharmacist must assign the level of supervision (Appendix 1) for the scheme. The level of supervision can be re-assessed on a new form as required.
Registered Nurse and/or Registered Pharmacist must complete a consent form (Appendix 3). One copy must be given to the parent and the other placed within the patient medical records.

All current medication will be prescribed on an in-patient prescription chart as per the Trust Prescribing of Medicines policy, or equivalent. A ‘Parent Medication Policy' sticker (SOU4671) must be placed on the front of the in-patient medication chart.
Medication use and administration

Children's own medication may be used, but must be checked for suitability (correct labeling, expiry date, integrity of packaging etc.) by either a member of the pharmacy team or the registered nurse when the parent medication scheme is commenced. If the medications are unsuitable then they must be returned to pharmacy for disposal or relabeling.
If a new drug is prescribed, a supply must be obtained from Pharmacy.

If the child's own medication is not available, this should be obtained from home prior to starting the scheme. Where this is not possible, nursing staff to discuss alternative routes of supply with the pharmacy team. It is important to recognise the individual circumstances for each child on a case by case basis.

Any medication needed from pharmacy will be labeled with dosage instructions. Ward stock medicines must never be given to a parent for administration because these are not appropriately labeled. Outside Pharmacy working hours, registered nurses must take responsibility for administering drugs, until an appropriately labeled medicine is obtained.

A Registered Nurse or Pharmacist will counsel the parent regarding medications they are able to give under the policy. A copy of Appendix 2 must be given to the parents by the Nurse and/or Pharmacist. This must be returned to staff if the medication is changed on the drug chart and any further changes should be made and returned to the parent.
Any medicines administered by the nursing staff must be recorded accordingly on the drug chart.
Page  of
Parental responsibilities

The parents must be given a key to the parent drug locker and all medication stored in the locker at all times. A key to the parent drug locker must also be held by the nursing staff. When received, the key must be signed for by the parent and also on completion of the parent medication scheme when it is returned.
All parents involved in the care of the child whilst in hospital must be assessed on an individual basis.
The parents can then administer all of the child's regular medications.
The drug chart must be completed after every dose of drug given by the parents. Parents should sign each administration with the code ‘9' ( parent administration)

The drug chart must be checked by a registered nurse throughout the 24 hour period to ensure that all medications have been administered correctly and the drug chart signed appropriately. If the drug chart has not been completed by the parent the patient should be withdrawn from the policy.
Prior to discharge
The ward pharmacist must be notified of the predicted date of discharge at the earliest opportunity.
The medical staff must review the medication chart and, make any changes necessary.

If the medication prescription remains the same on discharge, the patient's own medication brought from home may be returned by the nurse. However, any additional supplies obtained from the pharmacy during admission must be re-labeled by pharmacy prior to discharge, except where these have already been dispensed in readiness for discharge. The discharge prescription must include all the medication the child is taking regardless of supplies held or changes to medication.

Any medicines no longer needed must be returned to pharmacy in accordance with Trust policy and any medication stopped prior to discharge must be clearly documented in the discharge letter communicated to the parent and GP.
If felt necessary parents may be re-counselled before discharge and a compliance check completed.
Page  of
Patient own medications
If a parent does not want to participate in the parent medication policy all their medications should be removed from them and checked that they are correctly labelled and within the use by date.
The medications should then be written on Appendix 4 and signed in by both parent and nurse.
The medications should then be stored appropriately, in line with MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines, and can be used by the nursing team during the patients stay.
Any medications that have expired should be returned to pharmacy for disposal after parents have been informed.
Any medications where the label is incorrect or unclear, should be directed to the   pharmacy team to assess suitability for use of dispensed items (patient's own
medications) and re-dispense / re-label items where indicated. If a controlled drug   needs relabeling, this must be done in line with MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs
Policy.

On discharge medications should be returned to the parent and signed out on Appendix 4. All controlled drugs (patient's own or dispensed with directions for the patient from pharmacy) must be signed out of the patient's own CD register. The parent should sign the register with the nurse for the receipt of the medication to take home. Under no circumstances should controlled drugs dispensed for inpatient use only with no directions be given to the parent or sent home.
Training requirements
Both teaching and training will take place during induction for nursing, medical and pharmacy staff working on the Children's wards.
Page  of
Monitoring compliance

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Paediatric Guideline Steering Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local documents for paediatrics. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the site Paediatric and Neonatal Guideline Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranet.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 5)
Page  of
References
Williams L, Caldwell N, Collins E. Helping parents / carers to give medicines to   children in hospital. Arch Dis Child 2016 Sep; 101(9):e2.
East Suffolk and North Essex NHS Foundation Trust. Document PP(16) 067d Parent Administration of Medicines (PAM) Procedure Version 3.
Page  of
Parent administration of medication in paediatrics policy / MSEPO-21xxx / 0.03
Appendix 1: Levels of supervision for parent administration of drugs
This is to be completed EVERY admission and to be filed in the patient notes

table_items.text: FULL NURSE ADMINISTRATION: (responsibility and accountability of nursing staff) Nurse administers drugs from lockable Parent drug locker and signs for the drugs administered

FULL SUPERVISION: (responsibility and accountability of nursing staff) The nurse/pharmacist teaches the parent how to administer medicines and explain their purpose. Nurse administers drugs from lockable Parent drug locker with the parent and signs for the drugs administered

FULL PARENT ADMINISTRATION: (parent holds responsibility, nurse holds accountability) The parent has the key and has been assessed as requiring no supervision. The parent administers the drugs and alerts the nurse when doses given, nurse signs chart. At regular intervals the nurse checks with the parent that they have administered the drugs and that all doses have been signed for
